answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some resources that may be helpful.
Below are the code enforcement guidelines from Oklahoma City. They specifically mention broken windows.
http://www.okc.gov/neighborhood/code/enforce.html 
I found a similar code from Leavenworth, KS.
http://www.lvks.org/department/division.asp?fDD=15-74
In Vallejo, CA Property Maintenance Ordinance they also mention broken windows.
http://www.ci.vallejo.ca.us/GovSite/default.asp?serviceid1=90&Frame=L1
I also included the Abandoned of Foreclosed Property Registration and Maintenance Ordinance from Macomb County, MI. They also have an ordinance dealing just with broken windows.
http://www.macomb-mi.gov/Building/VacantPropertyRegistrationOrdinance.pdf
This article is about dealing with the up keep of foreclosed and vacant properties.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/7689/Clean_It_or_Lien_It_Dealing_With_Foreclosed_or_Abandoned_Properties
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Timothy McLean
text: I am interested in hearing about any ordinances that local governments have regarding broken windows. We are considering passing an ordinance on this issue that is similar to the International Property Maintenance Code. So I would like to hear if any communities have an ordinance that deals strictly with broken windows. Because blight ordinances are difficult to enforce, I am trying to stay away from that terminology. Any information would be extremely helpful.
title: Broken Window Ordinances
